title: 7 hidden features in LibreOffice Calc that make it a worthy Excel replacement
description: See these hidden features that make LibreOffice Calc better than MIcrosoft Excel.
author: Parth Shah
excerpt: See these hidden features that make LibreOffice Calc better than MIcrosoft Excel.
text: When it comes to spreadsheets, many think Excel is the only game in town. But what if I told you there is a powerful, free alternative hiding in plain sight? LibreOffice Calc is a free open-source spreadsheet program that can give Excel a run for its money. This isn’t just another stripped-down version of Excel (looking at you, OnlyOffice) but rather a comprehensive tool equipped with robust features, advanced calculations, and data analysis capabilities. In this post, I will go over the hidden capabilities of LibreOffice Calc that make it a compelling alternative to Excel for both casual and power users. Related 7 Compatibility with Excel files Don’t leave your existing spreadsheets behind Compatibility is the first thing that comes to mind when someone is looking to replace their existing Excel setup. The good news is that LibreOffice Calc is designed with excellent compatibility in mind (.xls, .xlsx, and .xlsm), and it ensures that you can seamlessly continue working with your existing Excel files. I imported my current Excel workbook into LibreOffice, which did the job just fine. The workbook has multiple sheets with Pivot tables and charts, and LibreOffice completes the process without breaking a sweat (there was only an issue with Aptos fonts, and it looked weird on Calc). Power users can also download third-party Excel templates from the web and use them with LibreOffice. 6 Powerful Solver Solve engineering challenges Hidden behind the Tools menu, Solver is a robust tool for finding the best solutions to complex problems. When your problem involves multiple variables, Solver’s sophisticated algorithms come into play to deliver the best outcome for your objective function. Suppose you are a farmer with 100 acres of land and considering three types of crops: wheat, corn, and soybeans. Here, each crop has different water requirements, profitability per acre, and labor needs. You can use Solver to define variables, set constraints (land, water, and labor availability), define the objective (that would be to maximize profile), and run it to find how many acres to dedicate to each crop to achieve the highest profit (given the resources). Its capabilities are endless. 5 Goal Seek Ideal for financial planning Goal Seek is a handy feature for determining what input value you need to achieve a specific target result. It’s like working backward. Suppose you are saving up or a down payment on a new apartment. You have a savings goal of $500,000, and you're currently investing your money in a fixed deposit with an annual interest rate of 7%. Now, you need to calculate how much you need to invest to reach your goal in five years. You can add cells for initial investment, interest rate, and investment period. Use Goal Seek (under the Tools menu) to tell you the exact amount you need to invest initially to reach your savings goal of $500,000 in five years at a 7% interest rate. 4 Scenario manager Explore different possibilities If you want to analyze multiple what-if scenarios for better decision-making, use Scenarios to get insights into potential outcomes under various conditions. Suppose you are planning a music concert. You are uncertain about factors like the number of attendees, ticket price, and sponsorship amounts. You want to explore different combinations of these factors to see how they impact the overall funds received (revenue) and make informed decisions. You can define input variables, create scenarios (Tools -> Scenarios), define output cells, and analyze scenarios to calculate net profit. 3 Macro support Automate your spreadsheets If you are a power macros user on Excel, you should feel right at home with LibreOffice Calc. You can record a macro to automate repetitive tasks within the spreadsheet. You can automate formatting, manipulate data, create custom functions, and do much more. Such a practice saves time, reduces errors, and increases efficiency and consistency. Related 2 Data pilot Analyze your data like a pro Similar to Pivot tables in Excel, LibreOffice offers a Data pilot to summarize and analyze large datasets quickly and easily. You can summarize data by different categories, such as sum, average, count, max, min, etc., drag-and-drop fields to rearrange the layout, explore data from different angles, and generate charts and graphs directly from the Data Pilot table to visualize your findings. Suppose you have a large database of sales transactions with different details (date of sale, product name, region, revenue, quantity sold, and salesperson); you can use data pilot to summarize sales by region, track sales trends over time, identify top performers, and visualize sales distribution. 1 Free and open-source Say goodbye to subscriptions While it’s not exactly a hidden feature of LibreOffice in general, the open-source nature is still worth talking about. LibreOffice source code is publicly available as part of an open-source project, and anyone can inspect, modify, and contribute to its development. The open-source nature promotes transparency, as anyone can examine the code for any potential security breaches or backdoors. Besides, it’s completely free to download and use. Unlock spreadsheet freedom with LibreOffice Calc LibreOffice Calc proves that you don't need to break the bank for powerful spreadsheet software. Its impressive array of features, including advanced analysis tools, macro support, and cross-platform compatibility, makes it a compelling alternative to Excel. It strikes the perfect balance between Google Sheets and Excel. If you don’t want to subscribe to Microsoft 365 (especially after a recent price hike) or feel overwhelmed with Excel’s never-ending features list, give LibreOffice Calc a try. If you are still thinking about using LibreOffice, check out the top reasons why it’s the perfect alternative to Microsoft 365.
